reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Three Threads, One Story Well And Intricately Woven
reviews.reviewText: This book follows the separate stories of Mitsuo Fuchida who led the attack on Pearl Harbor, a Doolittle Raider, and the daughter of missionaries caught up in the Japanese invasion of the Philippines. For those interested in World War II (as I am), the story begins very appropriately with the lead-up to the attack on Pearl Harbor. It then follows Fuchida (certainly the main person of interest for most readers) during the historical attack, and then through Midway, the end of the war, the surrender of Japan, and his search for meaning in the wake of those dramatic events. While overall this book definitely rates 5 stars, there were a couple things that could have made it more enjoyable. The hopscotching between the three storylines (one of which splits in two, adding a fourth thread to keep track of) is a little too frequent, with some of the “hops” occasionally comprising only a terse few sentences. This made the story feel a little fragmented rather than cohesive at times. Also, the three story threads are not brought together until very late in the book, though I will say that when this finally occurs it is done so adeptly that it satisfactorily offset my complaint here. The bottom line is that this is great read for anyone interested in Mitsuo Fuchida’s journey, both historical and religious. Well recommended!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Skeptics Say Coincidence, Believers Say Miracles
reviews.reviewText: I met Mitsuo Fuchida in 1970 when I was a waiter at the original Old Spaghetti Factory in Portland Oregon. He was in the lounge by the bar with a large party waiting to be seated. I was goimg back and forth to the bar, getting drinks for my customers, and kept hearing them calling him “Mits” or “Reverend Fuchida”. I’d read “Day of Infamy” by Walter Lord at Punahou in 8th Grade, and thought “Mits… Mits Fuchida…” On my third or fourth trip to the bar, curiosity overcame silence, and I told his interpreter “Excuse me Sir, but I couldn’t help overhearing your group refer to this Gentleman as Mits or Rverend Fuchida. If I’m not mistaken, Commander Mitsuo Fuchida led the attack on Pearl Harbor—“ At that point, Revered Fuchida, who understood English better than he could speak it, looked up in my eyes, and with a sad smile said in heavily accented English“Zattu wasu me.” I was holding a tray wiith drinks.Reverend Fuchida brought his hand up toward me as if he was offering to shake it, but noting that my hands were full, quickly withdrew it as we both shrugged slightly and chuckled at the inability to shake hands. For a fleeting moment I imagined dumping my drinks on him, but quelled the thought as his interpreter told me he had given his life over to the Gospel of Christ, and was now an Evangelical Minister, here in Portland for a Crusade. I still consider that moment as one of the most remarkable in my life so far. And reading “Wounded Tiger” has certainly reaffirmed the Miracle of God’s Lovein my own Heart, Mind, Body, Soul and Spirit.Bill SageHonolulu1.17.2024

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A book to read.
reviews.reviewText: I read lots of books and most of them don't make much of an impression on me. This one did. If you like a good story, this is a good story - and not fiction. If you like the history of World War II in the Pacific, this is the book for you as it covers some of the key events of that part of the war. If you like books that pull out your emotions, this one is for you and even if you don't like to get emotional you need to read it anyway. If you're an avowed Christian, this is a book you need to read to firm up who you're supposed to be. If you're not a Christian, then this is the book you definitely should read. It could change your life.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars 11 year old son really likes this book
reviews.reviewText: My son is 12 this month, and is into survival type books, stranded type books, and war history books (I Survived, Boxcar children, and any appropriate age war books that gives descriptions of the planes/vehicles).I bought this from amazons search option “ war books for 12 year old boys”, and this popped up. After reading the reviews, I figured I’d give it a try.As soon as he opened it, he skimmed through it reluctantly, but soon became immersed in it. He was on page 100 within two after school days.He was quoted “this is a really good book”

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The truth will set you free
reviews.reviewText: ust finished reading Wounded Tiger.Wow. What a fabulous story. I read with constant intrigue learning details I've not known about this war even though all 5 of my children loved learning about this war and its many different sides. My children looked forward to watching Tora, Tora, Tora at least once a year! Now I understand it's importance. So many tears shed for the depth of the lives lost or the torture and then the finale of coming to Christ, the ultimate reward.Well done. Thank you,

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book is excellent. Short chapters direct to the point. The Japanese people were misled by a corrupt government and complicit press. Sound familiar?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Inspired Writing Masterfully Brought to Life by Amazing Photos!
reviews.reviewText: In over 70 years of reading great books, I rate this as number ONE. Never a wasted word & brought to life with high quality photographs inserted conveniently in the text, throughout. In the past I had to read books of this type with a stack of reference books beside me showing pictures of ships, planes, maps, etc. Or pictures would be clumped together in only 2 or 3 places in the book; very unhandy & distracting. Also appreciated is the fact that this author has the skill to write a real “page turner” without the use of profanity! Masterfully written in great detail & skillfully formatted, reading this book is like being there. Wow! Thanks for the experience!!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A WWII untold great tale! It is also a healing tale as well.
reviews.reviewText: My husband and I are WWII babies. I am a Military Brat and a Vietnam veteran’s wife. We are also war history buffs with a tiny bit of admiration for Admiral Yamamoto. How the decision was made to spare the Emperor remained a mystery to us. This book reveals a good deal about the more obscure details. That said, I had spent August, 1957 in Tokyo with my field grade officer father who was on leave. Our family also traveled to an incredibly beautiful resort on a lake at the foot of Mt. Fuji. We were humbled by all our interactions with people in Japan. We know the history but have found difficulty with understanding the Japanese motives. This clears up some questions.
